qas.question: When did Thuringia become a landgraviate?
Which years were the War of the Thuringian Succession fought?
When did the western half of the state become Hesse?
Where was the Wettin dynasty from?
Who did the Saxon Duchies consist of?

answers.text: the states of Saxe-Weimar, Saxe-Eisenach, Saxe-Jena, Saxe-Meiningen, Saxe-Altenburg, Saxe-Coburg, and Saxe-Gotha

qas.question: When did Thuringia lose status as a landgraviate?
Which years were the War of the Thuringian Succession in peace?
When did the eastern half of the state become Hesse?
Where was the Wettin dynasty forbidden?

plausible_answers.text: the states of Saxe-Weimar, Saxe-Eisenach, Saxe-Jena, Saxe-Meiningen, Saxe-Altenburg, Saxe-Coburg, and Saxe-Gotha

qas.question: Who did the Saxon Duchies imprison?

context: Thuringia became a landgraviate <a0_0>in <b5_0>1130 AD<b5_0/><a0_0/>. After the extinction of the reigning Ludowingian line of counts and landgraves in <a2_0><b7_0>1247<b7_0/><a2_0/> and the War of the Thuringian Succession (<a1_0><b6_0>1247–1264<b6_0/><a1_0/>), the western half became independent under the name of "Hesse", never to become a part of Thuringia again. Most of the remaining Thuringia came under the rule of the Wettin dynasty of the nearby <a3_0><b8_0>Margraviate of Meissen<b8_0/><a3_0/>, the nucleus of the later Electorate and Kingdom of Saxony. With the division of the house of Wettin in 1485, Thuringia went to the senior Ernestine branch of the family, which subsequently subdivided the area into a number of smaller states, according to the Saxon tradition of dividing inheritance amongst male heirs. These were the "Saxon duchies", consisting, among others, of <a4_0><b9_0>the states of Saxe-Weimar, Saxe-Eisenach, Saxe-Jena, Saxe-Meiningen, Saxe-Altenburg, Saxe-Coburg, and Saxe-Gotha<b9_0/><a4_0/>; Thuringia became merely a geographical concept.
